title: 105_s2433
content: TITLE X--FINANCIAL INFORMATION PRIVACY PROTECTION is added to the Consumer Credit Protection Act to enhance financial information privacy. The Financial Information Privacy Act, under TITLE X of the Consumer Credit Protection Act, includes sections on definitions, privacy protection for customer information, enforcement, civil liability, criminal penalties, relation to State laws, and agency guidance. The Act defines terms like "customer" and "customer information of a financial institution" to regulate the handling of customer data by financial institutions. The term 'financial institution' refers to any institution providing financial services to customers with credit, deposit, trust, or other financial accounts. It includes depository institutions, loan companies, credit card issuers, and consumer reporting agencies. The Federal Reserve may define 'financial institution' for privacy protection regulations. It is prohibited to obtain customer information through false pretenses. The text prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution through deception, including making false statements or providing forged documents to deceive employees into releasing the information. The text prohibits soliciting someone to obtain customer information from a financial institution under false pretenses. Law enforcement agencies are exempt from this prohibition, as are financial institutions conducting security testing. The text prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution under false pretenses, with exceptions for security testing and law enforcement agencies. Compliance with this rule is enforced by the Federal Trade Commission. The Federal Trade Commission enforces compliance with the title, with the same power as under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. In certain cases, other agencies like the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency enforce compliance for specific financial institutions. The Federal Reserve Act, Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Office of Thrift Supervision, and National Credit Union Administrator oversee compliance for various financial institutions. The Office of Thrift Supervision and the National Credit Union Administration oversee compliance for financial institutions. Violations of this title are treated as violations of other laws, and state authorities also have the power to take action for violations. State authorities have the power to enforce violations of this title by bringing actions in court to enjoin violations, recover damages on behalf of residents, and be awarded costs and attorney fees. Prior notice must be served to the Federal Trade Commission for any action involving a financial institution. State authorities can enforce violations by bringing actions in court, with prior notice to the Federal Trade Commission for actions involving financial institutions. The FTC or relevant agency can intervene, be heard on all matters, remove the action to a district court, and file appeals. State authorities can enforce violations by bringing actions in court, with prior notice to the Federal Trade Commission for actions involving financial institutions. The FTC or relevant agency can intervene, remove the action to a district court, and file appeals. No State can bring an action under this section against a defendant named in a complaint by the FTC while a federal action is pending. "Any person failing to comply with this title regarding financial institutions or customer information is liable for actual damages sustained by the institution or customer, plus any benefits received from the non-compliance. Additional damages may also be imposed." Sec. 1006 outlines criminal penalties for violating section 1003, including fines and imprisonment. Sec. 1007 clarifies that this title does not supersede state laws. Sec. 1007 clarifies that this title does not supersede state laws, except in cases of inconsistency. State laws providing greater protection than this title are not considered inconsistent. Sec. 1008 requires Federal banking agencies to issue advisories to assist depository institutions in deterring prohibited activities under section 1003. Before the end of the 18-month period, the Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress on the effectiveness of remedies in addressing fraudulent attempts to obtain financial information and recommendations for legislative or regulatory actions to address threats to financial privacy.
